key_insight: A meta-learning-based controller embedded in O-RAN can quickly adapt handover policies per cell and user, striking a practical balance between Traditional Handovers (THOs) and Conditional Handovers (CHOs) to reduce failures and delays across large, heterogeneous NextG deployments.
problem_solved: Mitigates high HO failure rates, latency, and inefficient signaling/resource use in dense and high-frequency mobile networks by automatically selecting and adapting THO vs CHO strategies to local mobility and radio conditions.
method: Meta-learning framework: meta-train across many cells/areas so the model learns transferable HO strategy priors.
Fast online adaptation: fine-tune the prior with a few local samples to optimize per-cell/user HO decisions (THO vs CHO) under current conditions.
O-RAN integration: implement as a near-RT RIC xApp for real-time decisioning that balances reliability, signaling overhead, and resource reservation.
impact: Demonstrates how meta-learning enables rapid adaptation in non-stationary, heterogeneous telecom environments, reducing data needs and deployment latency — a practical pattern AI/ML practitioners can apply to other edge-network control problems.
visual_elements: Architecture diagram: O-RAN with near-RT RIC xApp making THO/CHO decisions, showing data flows from RU/CU/DU to the xApp.
Bar chart: comparison of HO failure rate, latency, and signaling overhead for baseline (THO-only, CHO-only) vs proposed meta-learning controller.
Map/heatmap: countrywide cells colored by improvement in reliability or adaptation speed after fine-tuning.
Flowchart: meta-training stage → deployment → few-shot online adaptation cycle for a single cell/user.
paper_title: Meta-Learning-Based Handover Management in NextG O-RAN
paper_authors: Michail Kalntis, George Iosifidis, José Suárez-Varela, Andra Lutu, Fernando A. Kuipers
